comments.text:
+yearswriter Well there is a theory in quantum mechanics (quantum 
information theory especially) that time is the measurement of quantum 
entanglement, which behaves pretty much like thermodynamics, but not with 
energy, but with causality. Lets say you go into a room you have never been 
before. The particles in your body would get entangled with the particles 
in the room, so their states have influence on the states of your 
particles. If you would want to calculate the probability of a particle of 
your body having a specific state, you would need to include all the 
entangled particles in your calculations. Even if you leave the room, your 
particles keep their entanglement and never lose it. So from the big bang 
to now, every particle has been entangled with a big bunch of other 
particles, thus influencing their states of superposition and getting 
influenced by them. As particles can't seem to lose these entanglements 
naturally, they can only increase in amount, thus behaving quite similar to 
what we call time.

I can search for the link to the paper if anyone is interested.
comments.author: Emanuel May

comments.text:

doesn't make them the same thing :)
comments.author: Tim Kasem

comments.text:
+Z6U6Z6U Well, that would mean the universe is a giant memory bank, storing 
the state of every particle in every point in time. Quantum theory says, a 
state of a particle is unknown (to us AND the universe) until it is 
observed. Going backwards in time would result in particles going back into 
superpositions, losing entanglement and so on. There are two possibilities 
I can think of:
1. Quantum mechanics is wrong and the universe stores every state in time. 
That would mean we can go backwards and forwards in time, like we want to. 
But everything we observed about small particles leads to quantum mechanics 
being true.
2. Quantum mechanics is true and every particle in a superposition is 
described as a probability function (instead of real values). That would 
mean going backwards in time could result in a different past (while going 
backwards) because particles would not be going back the exact same way 
they came before, just the most probable one. But if the past itself would 
be changed all of a sudden, we could definitely observe that. As we do not 
observe any spontaneous fluctuations in time, we can be pretty sure we are 
not going backwards in time "sometimes".

If there is anything wrong with my statements above, please do correct me :)

+UnknownXV well, volume is basically radius cubed. So dividing mass by 
radius or by volume yields a different outcome... But that isn't even the 
point. There is no density criterion or threshold for an object to become a 
black hole. For example: the densest form of matter we know of are nucleons 
(protons and neutrons). If black holes formed from a great density field, 
then nucleons would be black holes, but they're not (fortunately!). The 
real criterion is the compacity parameter (or relativity parameter). 
Nucleons aren't black holes because they have a very low compacity. Earth

to 1 (depending on the definition)... Hope this cleared out the confusion :)

+MarshallLore Actually, black holes are not dense at all, they are 
virtually denseless. What counts is the relativity parameter (aka 
compacity). When an object's compacity passes a threshold, it becomes a 
black hole. Density is irrelevant. Black holes are compact but not dense.

comments.author: Decodeish1

comments.text:
+UnknownXV Astronomers generally consider the event horizon to be the 
boundary of a black hole, so to say a black hole has no volume is a common 
mistake: the black hole is the region of space enclosed by the event 
horizon. The singularity at the center does has zero volume and contains 
all the mass. (In a real black hole there would be matter and energy 
falling into it, and so there would be mass present outside the singularity 
as well.)
The event horizon itself is a spherical surface, with a definite 
circumference, and so encloses a nonzero volume. However, due to the 
extreme curvature of a black hole's interior, the radius you get from 
measuring the circumference is NOT the same as the black hole's actual 
radius. Since space is infinitely curved at the singularity, you could say 
this radius is infinite. 
Basically black holes have finite circumference, infinite radius and 
volume, but the mass is concentrated in a point of zero volume at the 
center. A black hole totally can contain mass just as anything else, since 
mass is really just space-time curvature.
comments.author: Lynnie Saade

comments.text:

Well, Neutron stars just aren't large enough to hold together things like 
galaxies. What I meant by in my previous post was that black holes don't 
exist in the traditional definition that we currently go by, but with a 
different one. In the new definition, black holes don't have an event 
horizon, and light, matter and information CAN escape, albeit really far in

comments.text:
+Megaprr
Please ignore that article. Whoever wrote that does not understand the 
difference between a gravitational singularity and the Big Bang.

There is nothing in real science I have ever heard of that postulates 
universes are born from white holes. The science behind a white hole is 
simply a mirror of the geometry of a Schwartzchild black hole using the 
Kruskal-Szekeres coordinate system. The geometry shows the white hole is in 
the infinite past. They do not exist since they violate the Laws of 
Thermodynamics. The collapse of a star into a black hole using those same 
coordinates is different from what really happens as according to GR (We 
need a theory of quantum gravity to have one system for a collapsing star 
and a black hole).

If the writer was going off of that. He does not realize to look at the 
bigger picture. The Kruskal-Szekeres coordinate are part of General 
Relativity. GR has time symmetry. Everything in the opposite symmetry 
fundamentally violates the Laws of Thermodynamics (Time can't run in 
reverse, just as you cannot unmix ingredients). A reversal of time is 
reversing entropy, that's a no-no. GR is differomorphism invariant. We 
ignore everything on the "other side of time." because it's not really 
there. General covariance is a product of physics, not reality.

Let's go a step further. Ignore the general invariance of GR. According the 
the coordinate system, the white hole and black hole are connected via a 
Lorentzian wormhole existing at *about* the center. The problem is, it's 
mirrored on the other side. The entryways do not connect. So instead of 
hitching a ride to reverse-time land, you get trapped in the Schwartzchild 
bubble then smashed into and become one with the singularity. 
Theoretically, if it did exist, when you're inside the bubble, you should 
be able to "see" the other universe through the wormhole.

One further, if the entries connected, the sheer amount of matter that 
would need to be accreted is truly profane. The universe had a *whole* lot 
more stuff in the beginning. We only exist thanks to the apparent baryon 
asymmetry. The universe started out with a whole lot more matter, but it 
annihilated with its antimatter counterparts. There was slightly more 
baryonic matter than antibaryonic matter. If there was a balance, nothing 
would exist except pure energy from everything annihilating. To the point, 
for a whitehole to spit out enough energy to form a universe like ours, the 
singularity need to be VASTLY more massive than 30 sexdecillion kilograms 
(That's a 30 with 51 zeros or 3e+52kg). That number is the estimated mass 
of the observable universe. The universe is probably many, many, many, 
many, *many* times that size. I'm not going to say that's not possible. 
Size is relevant only to us. If there are other universes, ours could be 
microscopic in relation to another, just as our Sun is microscopic as 
compared to other stars. There is no known fundamental limit to the mass of 
our universe given it is spread out enough so that it's not so dense that 
it surpasses the Schwartzchild radius and collapses into a black hole. To 
give an example of said radius, if you take Earth and crunch it into a ball 
about 8.8mm, gravity will take over and collapse it into a black hole.

http://casa.colorado.edu/~ajsh/schwp.html does a good job of explaining all 
of that about black holes and white holes and Schwartzchild geometry and 
whatnot.

To the point of the video. I have a hard to believing it is a white hole. 
That doesn't seem plausible to me. Why would it be where it is? Its 
location makes no sense. A long GRB where there is nothing capable of 
emitting such energy is strange but whiteholes are too far fetched. Quantum 
Mechanics can pull off some truly, unique, for lack of a better word, 
things. A GRB is nothing more than photons, so why not some sort of 
unfathomably low chance of an entire GRB from a supernova managing to 
tunnel via a gravitational wormhole from quantum entanglement out of the 
mess and into where it is? We know photons can mysteriously vanish and 
reappear literally anywhere (Calculable probability, quantum indeterminacy 
if I recall correctly), so I'd go for that or quantum entanglement before 
white holes.

There literally is more evidence to say it was a random quantum fluctuation 
than to say it was a white hole and I don't like either answers. A quantum 
fluctuation of that magnitude? I don't think so. That's some seriously 
doubtful odds. I don't think you could fit enough zeroes into the entire 
universe to show those odds. We're talking trillions upon trillions upon 
trillions of photons, each being tunneled to the appropriate location. It 
can happen but damn, them odds. If anybody would like to correct me on any 
points, feel free. I'll admit, I don't know everything and I probably got a 
few things wrong and damn, I wrote a lot more than I thought I did.

Entropy can be easily explained through chemistry, for me at least. Imagine 
water, in a liquid state. before i start, understand that each of the three 
phases (gas, liquid, and solids) have an arrangement of atoms in them: in 
solids the atoms don't move around and they pretty much stay in their 
position, in liquid the atoms are more free and move around but still 
restricted in a way, and in gas the atoms just go everywhere and fly 
everywhere and not held together. If we take water in a liquid form, the 
atoms are moving around a little freely, when you freeze water and it 
becomes solid ice, the atoms are restricted from their movements and and 
don't move; they have more order, less disorder. If water is heated up to 
gas, the atoms are moving all around and become more free, the order they 
had which restricted their movement a little is gone and thus the atoms 
became in a state of no order at all holding them done, they are 
experiencing disorder. This is what he meant bu the analogy, the piano is a 
fixed structure with the wood all stuck together forced to be in a certain 
shape. If you chop it in a wood chipper, it loses this order and 
experiences disorder. And so, as he states, you can take that wood and 
build anything, even another piano, because it is in such disorder the 
fragments are free to create anything basically, AS LONG AS IT IS THE SAME 
MASS, thus the entropy did not change. The reason it can't work backwards 
is because once you have a piano, you can't make anything out of the piano 
it's stuck that way. This is why, when referring back to water, the atoms 
can become anything when they experience entropy, they can be solid as you 
add more order and it can be gas as you add more disorder. I really hope 
you understand and I hope I did not make it worse x_x

comments.text:
+Maka Crimon No. What's at the centre of black holes is... Confusing. It 
isn't matter because it's too dense, it isn't energy because it's way too 
dense for that. It doesn't have a configuration, it's a compact mass held 
together by gravity. Gravity is an attractive force, meaning that if you 
inject energy into a system operating gravitationally, it increases in 
size. Anything outside of a black hole thus has more potential energy than 
it would were it inside, so, in accordance with the second law, energy will 
tend to spread out more evenly, moving particles from a higher energy state 
to the lower energy state inside a black hole.

The analogy of a black hole being a battery is actually somewhat accurate 
for different reasons, however, and they have to do with quantum mechanics. 
Hawking radiation slowly bleeds energy off of the surface of a black hole, 
but even that operates in accordance with the second law. Energy wants to 
be spread evenly in a homogeneous layer, a black hole is still a 
concentration, so over time, they evaporate, creating a uniform cloud of 
energy, at this point, we see heat death. There is zero usable energy in 
the universe (or smaller system of the black hole) because it is 
homogeneous, there is no gradient left for it to move across. It ends 
without so much as a whimper, everything stops moving, save for quantum 
fluctuations.
comments.author: Teth47

+Promethor Einstein once said the most incomprehensible thing about the 
universe was that it was apparently comprehensible. Of course, everything 
that APPEARS to hold exactly COULD just be merely approximately true. 
Kinetic energy is m*v^2/2 according to Newton, but 
m*v^2/(1-v^2/c^2+sqrt(1-v^2/c^2)) by Einstein, which is very, very close to 
m*v^2/2 for v much less than c, for instance. You're thinking that under 
extreme enough conditions, other things that seem to match observations 
under conditions that have been observed could fail. Sure. And making undue 
assumptions is what scientists most try not to do, I believe. Or at least 
it should be. And when that happens, it's often a facepalm moment for the 
entire world, just like in 1905, when they realize it should have been 
something they saw all along. To that, I say, you can't just proudly 
proclaim "everything you know is wrong, and the only true knowledge is that 
you know nothing" for so long. At some point, you're likely to get the 
right answers, or at least some of them. And maybe some of the answers that 
have been produced already ARE the correct answers. Sure, assume as little 
as you can, but you're never going to get anywhere if you try to proceed 
while assuming nothing. It really is possible to have the right answer at 
some point, as Einstein said, the universe is apparently comprehensible.

There is no difference aside from timescale. Life spanned billions of years 
before developing multicellular organisms, and still hundreds of millions 
before animals.
Know of any extinction events? These leave vacuums in ecological roles 
which greatly increases the selective pressures and niche potential of 
survivors, and therefore the rate of evolution as a whole (think of 
"topping" a tomato plant). We know of 24 within about ~600mya, 6 of which 
are commonly considered "mass extinctions"

incontrovertible. To me it seems useless to get hung up on this for the 
sake of a superiority complex. It's really quite a liberating and 
comforting idea discovering that you have a close relative in this 
biosphere. Similar, but distinct... They have much to teach you about 
yourself if you allow them.

comments.text:
My intent is not to mock, it is to understand why you actually believe in 
god.
See, here's the issue. You keep trying to chalk this discussion up to 
subjectivity, but I am not referring to the subjective. Anything truly 
observable is decidedly not subjective. 
We're born on earth here with a brain and sensory, which are our tools for 
figuring things out. Unless you have a better way of coming to truths than 
following what you can observe, then science is your tool for understanding 
everything. Everyone is born ignorant. Everything is there to be learned. 
This is all science is.
In your lifetime, you have observed something you can describe, which you 
explain using god because you believe nothing else suits it. Science does 
this too, except science is a self correcting communal process which 
explains things in terms of things we currently understand and freely 
admits faulty rationale as it's recognized.
If religious communities were more like the scientific community as a 
whole, it would recognize that *not everybody works with the same idea or 
definition of god* and would attempt to rectify this amongst themselves, 
using facts and not interpretation since the latter is inconsistent and 
subjective. They would find that there are no universal facts regarding 
god, that nobody attributes the same phenomena to god, and that no 
reasonable conclusion can be reached on this subject currently; which is my 
position exactly.

When you postulate about god your main piece of pro-reasoning is that 'we 
don't understand other things completely, so therefore god could exist in 
the cracks between our understanding'
I'll grant you this, but like you said yourself, possibility has no bearing 
on reality.
If you wish your beliefs to be contingent on reality, instead of referring 
to human ignorance to justify your reasoning, you should start referring to 
what we actually know.

P.S. I actually did counter. If you read between the lines, what I said was 
more or less along the veins of "that which can be asserted without 
evidence can be dismissed without evidence"
You have nothing rhetorically connecting gravity to god, so you haven't 
completed even the first layer of evidential reasoning, therefore it is not 
evidence.
And, by the way, if your god responds to *all* of your inquiries.. what 
would it have to say for people who have not been sufficiently convinced of 
its existence?

comments.text:
Daniel: Yes and no. Heat/radiation can still be used to do work as long as 
you have a temperature differential somewhere in the "system".
For example that "waste" heat could be used to heat water to steam and then 
drive a turbine.
But if all the energy in the world was converted to heat, and everywhere 
was the *same temperature*, then the heat would be useless.
And that's where the "number of states vs total number of possible states" 
definition of entropy comes into play, rephrasing the second law of 
thermodynamics: You can only ever go from a state with a lower number of 
possible states to one with a higher number.
For example: Ice cubes. There are significantly fewer ways water molecules 
can be arranged so that they form a crystalline structure than a liquid, so 
if you put ice cubes in a perfectly insulated container with some room 
temperature water, over time the ice cubes will always melt, averaging the 
temperature of the water in the container. The reverse will never happen, 
that a lukewarm pool of water will separate into one part boiling water and 
another part that is frozen with the average temperature remaining the same.

top_comment.author: Ibliss

comments.text:
It's simply more likely for entropy to decrease.  It's waaay more likely 
for a piano to turn into woodchips than woodchips to turn into a piano.  
Because it's more likely, it happens more often, and so nature is slowly 
increasing in entropy.  So you CAN decrease entropy on a small scale, but 
on the large scale it will always increase.  That law really applies only 
to the overall state of things, individual events can violate it.

I should also add that the law only applies to closed systems, which are 
systems with no outside influences.  For example, a piano in a sealed box 
will slowly deteriorate into rotted woodchips, and it will never turn back 
into a piano.  Entropy has increased in this closed system, and it can't 
decrease.  However, if you opened the box, which would make it no longer a 
closed system, you could reconstruct the piano.  The Universe is a closed 
system, so entropy decreases for it.
comments.author: FlyingPiper13

comments.text:
A restatement of the second law basically says that deltaS_system + 
deltaS_surroundings >= 0 where S_system + S_surroundings can be substituted 
for S_universe (because the system plus the surroundings is the universe). 
deltaS_universe >= 0, which can then be substituted as S_gen >= 0, which is 
a simple statement that no matter what happens either the entropy of the 
universe stays the same or increases (with S_gen = 0 only occurring when a 
process is 100% reversible and no work is lost in the process).
comments.author: hensroth

comments.text:
They aren't correct...entirely. You can decrease entropy - but the net

+Антон Кулиш The expansion wouldn't follow fractions initially though. A 
singularity is an object with 0 size. So, with a given mass it has no real 
density ( divide by zero error. ), which is often simply thought as 
infinite.

However, as soon as it starts to spew out matter as a White Dwarf, it now 
has a definite size and you can properly divide to find the actual density.

Since the density is not what is being divided, and that was the part that 
is sort of infinite, you don't end up dividing infinity by 2, 3, etc. It's 
the mass that is divided, and black holes have a specific mass. In the case 
of the super-massive black hole at the center of the Milky Way, it's 
approx. 4.1 million solar masses btw. That's 4.1 million times the mass of 
our sun.

comments.text:
+Zach Crawford What you say about the second law is true. However, the 
decrease in entropy needed here is massive. Entropy goes by the logarithm 
of the number of microstates (a possible configuration of the system, i.e. 
this particle is at position x, that particle is in position y, etc.) 
resulting in the same macrostate (in this case, the white hole). But the 
number of microstates goes by the factorial of the number of particles in 
the system. Considering there are (very roughly) 10^58 particles in the 
sun, and black holes form from stars much bigger than the sun, the number 
of possible states is on the order of (10^58)! where the exclamation point 
denotes the factorial. This means (1 followed by 58 zeroes) times (57 9's) 
times (56 9's followed by an 8) times (56 9's followed by a 7) and so on. 
Factorials grow extremely fast. So fast, in fact, that the number (10^58)! 
is so large that if you were to write it out in "long form," with say, font 
size 10, the number would be substantially longer than the diameter of the 
observable universe.
I'm jut saying, if you're going to say "it's possible" then yeah, it's 
definitely possible. But it's not going to happen. :(
It's actually far more likely that 6 billion people on the earth would 
simultaneously begin suffocating because air is only 21% oxygen and it's 
entirely possible that the random collision of atoms surrounding their head 
would bounce all of the oxygen molecules away from them, even though I can 
safely say from pure probabilities that such a thing has never happened to 
anyone. At a certain scale of probability, "it's possible" doesn't really 
mean anything.

comments.text:
+Dan Tozer There's almost no evidence to work with. All we have now is the 
observation of what could have been a white hole, the existence of which 
would contradict the second law of thermodynamics if it occurred 
spontaneously. If it was caused by sentient beings (in which case it almost 
certainly wasn't a white hole) then there could have been a mechanism that 
kept the total entropy change positive, and the 2nd law wouldn't have been 
violated.
So thus far we have a few options:
1) It was a white hole, meaning the 2nd law was violated which, while 
technically possible, is so unlikely on this scale that the odds of it 
happening are one in a number too big to be fit in the observable universe 
using this font size. 
2) It was some as of yet unknown phenomenon.
3) It was an alien beacon: not necessarily a white hole, but some 
intentional release of energy meant to simulate one.
I'm not at all saying I think it's option 3 (If I had to put money on it, 
I'd go with option 2). But I do think it deserves to be on the list, if for 
no other reason than because there's really no better way to show the rest 
of the galaxy there's sentient life somewhere than to create a luminous 
beacon that looks like a white hole.

comments.text:
And that's part of the problem with reversing time, and by extension 
causality.  It gets really complicated, really fast.  

White holes, if they exist, are the exact same as black holes.  They just 
work backward, because instead of time flowing forward and matter being 
sucked into them, time flows backward and matter is 'ejected' or more 
appropriately 'deabsorbed' if that's a word.

Where did they come from?  The future, wherein a black hole 'decayed', for 
lack of a better term, into a white hole.  It'd be going backward in time 
until it 'decayed' back into a black hole with time flowing normally again. 
 The best analogy I can think of might be a desk fan.  If you reverse time 
for it, it goes backward and propels air in reverse, but it's still a fan. 
 I feel obligated to say that I'm a layman and we have no idea if white 
holes even exist, much less in the way it's been imagined, so don't take 
this explanation of them as necessarily correct.

The big bang is too often referred to as a "Big explosion" though it's 
completely false. Science is based on observations, and we've observed that 
for instance a kilometer expands of a few nano meters every year due to the 
expansion of space. It is observable in light. We've also observed that the 
most far away objects are moving away from us faster. Space is therefore 
expanding. A simple regression in the expansion suggests that about 13 
billion years ago, the entirety of space was very small.

As for the black hole, it is not a "hole", it's a ball of matter with 
incredible density and incredible mass. If anything the black hole would be 
the pile, leaving regions next to it empty.

say that if ENOUGH mass is crushed into a SMALL enough volume, space time 
will collapse into a singularity. That distortion in space time is the same 
thing mass normally creates, except in this case, it's collapsed infinitely.

gravity is a function of mass - the singularity would have the same 
gravitational pull as the star it came from; except it doesn't. Space time 
has literally collapsed.

comments.text:
+AwesomeProMasterDude TheMasterOfEverything
Well, that's the point, an interval is an infinite set of real numbers with 
well defined boundaries. The size of such a set is its cardinality. We 
could be tempted to say N, the infinite set of all natural numbers, is 
twice as large as the infinite set of all even natural number, right? 
However, these sets have the same cardinality of aleph-null, i.e. the same 
infinity size. So that's why I asked about the intervals' cardinalities; 
you need to know them to order them.

I'm not aware of a theory other than set theory in mathematics which allows 
for different sizes of infinity. I'm genuinely interested to know about the 
one you seem to be referring to.

comments.text:
+Wan Pelar assuming you meant "The 'set' of all the possible intervals 
between A and B", the two sets you mentioned are in fact the same type of 
infinity, the same size if you wish. Why? Because there exists a bijection 
between them. Look into the work of Cantor if you want to know something 
more about this (fascinating) topic :).

+Rana Kamikaze Physicist don't like infinities just as you don't :), so I 
grant you that we would be very surprised if we could actually see an 
object with infinite density (see naked singularity and cosmic censorship). 
But technically even finite mass when compressed to infinitely small volume 
has infinite density. Since density is a ratio of mass/volume, there are 2 
independent limits that could make this ratio infinite: infinite mass, 
and/or infinitely small volume.

if your explanation of entropy was accurate then that would defeat the 
purpose of particle board, or wood boards made from previously destroyed 
wood, or when you take metal out of the earth and refine it into pure 
metal, which makes me think that why can't we reduce entropy? I can 
understand that overall the system gets more and more disordered, but parts 
could become more orderly﻿
top_comment.author: brandon carter

comments.text:
The reduction of entropy pretty much always requires a complex structure or 
some competing physical process that is powerful enough to overcome the 
statistical driving force behind entropy.  E.g.: A tree converting high 
entropy gas into low entropy structured cellulose or the disparate binding 
forces of water and oil causing separation of phases.

A black hole is basically just a big, dumb gravity hole that crushes 
everything that falls in.  There's not a lot of finesse there and almost 
certainly not any sort of mechanism that can do anything interesting with 
entropy.
comments.author: Dan Heidel

comments.text:
then could excess energy in a black hole be used to reduce it's own entropy 
and in turn increasing the entropy around itself with the explosion of 
matter and energy it would release?
comments.author: brandon carter

comments.text:
That's correct.  You can reduce entropy but only by expending energy to do 
so, causing a greater increase in entropy somewhere else.  That's the most 
basic definition of life in a nutshell - an object that lowers its internal 
entropy in a controlled fashion by increasing the entropy of its 
surroundings.

captions.text:
Okay, let me get this out of the way: white
holes are almost definitely not a real thing
that can be found in nature.

So keep that in mind when I say...we might
have seen one?
(INTRO)

In theory, white holes are black holes that
are going backwards.
In theory.

A black hole, as you know, is a giant object
that sucks stuff into a singularity - a single

point of infinite density - from which there
is no escape.

So a white hole would be an object that expels
matter from a singularity...and you’d never
be able to enter it.

White holes only exist in math. But in 2006,
we saw an explosion of light out in deep space
that we can't explain any other way.
It's...even weirder than it sounds.

In reality, a white hole would violate the
second law of thermodynamics. This says that

the amount of entropy in the universe can
only stay the same or increase. It can never
decrease.

Entropy is often described as disorder, but
it's more like a measure of how many different

states that particles in a system can be in
at any given moment.

Like, if you have a piano, and you throw it
in a woodchipper, you’ve increased the entropy

of the piano. Because a pile of chopped-up
piano splinters can be in lots and lots of

different configurations while still being...a
pile of splinters.

But these piano splinters can really only
be in one, very specific state in order to
be a piano.
At least ... a piano that works.

So, black holes are great at increasing entropy!
They’re the universe's woodchippers: shredding

entire stars into pulp, and leaving only a
whiff of radiation.

But you can't load your pile of piano splinters
into the woodchipper, and run the thing backwards

to get a piano again. That would decrease
entropy, which is not allowed. And if white

holes existed, that's essentially what they’d
do.

So why does anyone think white holes might
exist in the first place?

Well, they were first proposed as a kind of
mathematical oddity, because of Einstein’s
theories of relativity.

One of the many endearing quirks of relativity
is that it doesn't care whether you play time

backward or forward. If time can go in one
direction, it can just as easily go in the
other.

So if black holes are a thing, then white
holes - which are black holes played backward
- can also be a thing.

But just because relativity says time can
go in both directions, in practice it pretty
much sticks to one, as we all know.

So even if a white hole did somehow occur,
it would be incredibly unstable. Because the

universe DOES NOT LIKE IT when you break the
laws of physics! So a real white hole would

probably only last for a few seconds before
it collapsed in on itself to become a black
hole.

Which brings us back to the explosion we saw
in 2006.

Detected by NASA’s Swift satellite on June
14, it was a huge gamma ray burst: the highest-energy

type of explosion possible, a million trillion
times more energetic than the Sun.
And it lasted for…102 seconds.

Scientists believe that gamma ray bursts only
last that long during supernovas. But this

one, labeled GRB 060614, didn't have a supernova
to go with it.

As far as we can tell, it was an explosion
of white hot light that came from nowhere,
and then vanished.

And while white holes remain incredibly, stupendously,
ridiculously unlikely...that's pretty much
exactly what we think one would look like.

Some physicists have offered other explanations
for what it might’ve been -- like a shock

wave from neutron star torn apart by a black
hole, or maybe two neutron stars colliding.

But events like these only release energy
for two seconds at most -- not a minute and
a half.

So. White holes in nature are as impossible
as a thing can be, while still being technically
possible.

But they are technically possible. And until
we see another explosion like the one in 2006

that we could hopefully learn more from, we’ll
just have to wait, and wonder.

Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow
Space! And thanks to all of our Subbable subscribers

who make this channel possible! If you’d
like to support us and score some cool gear,
go to subbable.com/scishow to learn more.

And if you have questions or ideas for an
episode you’d like to see, you can find

us on Facebook and Twitter and in the comments
below, and if you want to keep getting smarter

with us, just go to YouTube.com/scishowspace
and subscribe!
